programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: Seto City, in Aichi Prefecture, is a leading ceramic hub, and also one of the Six Ancient Kilns of Japan . Its pottery tradition has continued uninterrupted for over 1,000 years. Ceramics are seen everywhere in stores, workshops and galleries, and even the landscape. Estella Mak, who is originally from Hong Kong, explores Seto, a pottery town filled with exceptional charms.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Master Chef's Class: Bo-sushi with chef Hayashi Ryohei
programme.desc: Join Harry Sugiyama for a fun new series as Master Chef Hayashi shares Kyoto-style salmon Bo-sushi you can make anywhere, plus his surprising 'gari' ginger twist!

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: A Device That Improves Children's Vision: Ishigaki Yo / Design Engineer / Professor, The University of Electro-Communications
programme.desc: Amblyopia is a condition where vision in one eye doesn't properly develop. Ishigaki Yo has created a device that improves vision through gaming. He talks about designing products that benefit society.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.desc: A-bomb survivor trees are treasured in Hiroshima. One cherry tree in a schoolyard has forged a bond with a former student, bringing her hope after the bombing and enduring joy. See more: https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/shows/5001460/

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: We need to be especially careful about health and medical information on the internet. This time, the father must come to terms with his "filter bubble" and learn that not every article is scientific proof. We also simplify concepts like "echo chamber" and "confirmation bias" to help you avoid common online pitfalls.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE:Night on the Town
programme.desc: A full moon shines above a bustling neighborhood. Featured prominently are kabuki theaters...on hiatus. Still, people have come out to take in the nightlife, and hopefully a celebrity sighting or two.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Threats from Above: Tackling Nuclear Plant Drone Intrusions
programme.desc: Unidentified lights appeared above Kyushu's Genkai Nuclear Power Station. A possible drone intrusion was suspected, but no visual record was captured by the plant's security system. Experts say the incident reveals a weakness in aerial security. Globally, drone intrusions into key facilities are occurring with increasing frequency. For instance, at the Kori Nuclear Power Plant in South Korea, about 60 percent of incidents remain untraced. As drone technology continues to advance, how should Japan and the international community respond? Guest: Suzuki Tatsujiro (Former Vice Chair, Japan Atomic Energy Commission, Cabinet Office)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Standing Bar Beside Fukuoka's Boat Racing Stadium
programme.desc: With betting tickets in hand, customers at a no-frills bar near a motorboat racing stadium in Fukuoka, ride the ups and downs of the exciting races. For three days, we followed their fortunes.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.desc: A US rapper, who discovers the legacy of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, is moved to meet hibakusha and join anti-nuclear groups. He sees parallels between their discrimination and that of African Americans.

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: In this episode, the father has become obsessed with a trendy beauty item for mice: the tail roller. Unaware of stealth marketing, his daughter must educate him about the importance of being aware of online promotion. Stealth marketing is now regulated in many countries, including Japan, where the new Consumer Affairs Agency guidelines state that even posts labeled as an advertisement can count as stealth marketing if consumers can't easily recognize the difference.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE: Folding Fans
programme.desc: We visit a store selling folding fans, where a young customer is having trouble making up his mind. The accessories were popular because the shape of the open fan symbolized increasing prosperity.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode features words related to neru, meaning "to sleep." Some data show that Japanese people average around only 7 hours of sleep a day, suggesting that many need more slumber. In fact, the Japanese language has a number of unique words related to sleep that describe various aspects of daily life. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through these expressions and the culture behind them.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #6 Does this train go to Ikebukuro?
programme.desc: Find out how to ask if public transportation goes to your destination. Use the name of the place plus "ni ikimasu ka".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: A Safe and Comfortable Society for All
programme.desc: A Sri Lankan student participates in the Mie Prefecture "Youth Police Supporters" volunteer program that works with communities to build a safer society by preventing crimes before they occur.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: "IMPACTS" uses science and data to convey the reality of climate change. A November series-coinciding with the COP30 summit in Brazil-featured five COP-related shows and an Amazon rainforest special.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Making the World Laugh: Atsuko Okatsuka / Stand-up Comedian
programme.desc: Atsuko Okatsuka is a US-based stand-up comedian with fans all over the world. She tells us why she pursues comedy, and talks about finding humor within the hardships of life in a minority group.

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Japanese festival favorite, yakisoba! Noodles cooked in a special sauce. Enjoy local yakisoba from all over Japan!

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: Fake information tends to spread widely during disasters like earthquakes. In this episode, a social media post warning about escaped cats puts the father in panic mode as he searches his house for any strays. We explain what to watch out for, especially with the increase in AI-created fake images.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE: Off to go Bathing
programme.desc: A mother and daughter brave the rain to visit their local bathhouse, exchanging words with a young girl along the way. We learn that regular bathing was an essential part of life for the townspeople.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Japan's Bear Threat Continues: What's Pushing Them Into Human Habitats?
programme.desc: Bear attacks continue to plague cities of Japan, with a record high number of deaths and injuries. In the northern city of Akita, where a series of sightings have occurred, many people refrain from going out, and a sense of urgency is spreading. One resident said, "It's as if there's someone with a knife hiding somewhere on the street." Recent research indicates that a dependence on human habitats can be passed down from parent bears to their cubs. We consider how to deal with the urban bear problem, which has entered a new phase. Guest: Ohnishi Naoki (Leader of the Animal Ecology and Genetics Team, Tohoku Research Center, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Suppai - The Secrets of Japan's Sour Treats
programme.desc: In Japan, the word for sourness is suppai. Since ancient times, people in Japan have preserved foods through fermentation. Sour Japanese tastes include vinegar, pickled plums and yuzu, a citrus fruit. Sour Japanese foods are often tied to culture and tradition. In one example, we see how, in Okinawa Prefecture, the juice of the shikwasa, another citrus fruit, is used to wash traditional bashofu cloth.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: A Long-Lasting Artificial Hip Joint To Change Your Life
programme.desc: Hip osteoarthritis causes severe pain and may require artificial hip joint surgery. A Japanese university and a company have developed a long-lasting artificial joint, offering hope to many patients.

programme.desc: How will PM Takaichi respond to Trump's unpredictability, and what could it mean for the alliance? Sheila A. Smith, CFR Senior Fellow, offers insight.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: Uncovering the Mysteries of Winter Lightning
programme.desc: In Japan, extremely powerful lightning known as a superbolt can occur in the Hokuriku region during winter. What is the source of this power, which is comparable to a small nuclear explosion?

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: A Long-Lasting Artificial Hip Joint To Change Your Life
programme.desc: Hip osteoarthritis causes severe pain and may require artificial hip joint surgery. A Japanese university and a company have developed a long-lasting artificial joint, offering hope to many patients.

programme.title: NHK NEWS 7
programme.desc: News 7 is NHK's flagship domestic evening news program, bringing you the latest from our Tokyo studio. It's presented with English audio on NHK World for our international viewers

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: Seto City, in Aichi Prefecture, is a leading ceramic hub, and also one of the Six Ancient Kilns of Japan . Its pottery tradition has continued uninterrupted for over 1,000 years. Ceramics are seen everywhere in stores, workshops and galleries, and even the landscape. Estella Mak, who is originally from Hong Kong, explores Seto, a pottery town filled with exceptional charms.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: A Device That Improves Children's Vision: Ishigaki Yo / Design Engineer / Professor, The University of Electro-Communications
programme.desc: Amblyopia is a condition where vision in one eye doesn't properly develop. Ishigaki Yo has created a device that improves vision through gaming. He talks about designing products that benefit society.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.desc: A-bomb survivor trees are treasured in Hiroshima. One cherry tree in a schoolyard has forged a bond with a former student, bringing her hope after the bombing and enduring joy. See more: https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/shows/5001460/

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: We need to be especially careful about health and medical information on the internet. This time, the father must come to terms with his "filter bubble" and learn that not every article is scientific proof. We also simplify concepts like "echo chamber" and "confirmation bias" to help you avoid common online pitfalls.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE:Night on the Town
programme.desc: A full moon shines above a bustling neighborhood. Featured prominently are kabuki theaters...on hiatus. Still, people have come out to take in the nightlife, and hopefully a celebrity sighting or two.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Master Chef's Class: Bo-sushi with chef Hayashi Ryohei
programme.desc: Join Harry Sugiyama for a fun new series as Master Chef Hayashi shares Kyoto-style salmon Bo-sushi you can make anywhere, plus his surprising 'gari' ginger twist!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Standing Bar Beside Fukuoka's Boat Racing Stadium
programme.desc: With betting tickets in hand, customers at a no-frills bar near a motorboat racing stadium in Fukuoka, ride the ups and downs of the exciting races. For three days, we followed their fortunes.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2025 - MOFs Changing the World (Science ZERO)
programme.desc: Dr. KITAGAWA Susumu was awarded the 2025 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs). In this program, we explore MOFs and their potential to help combat global warming.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: J-MELO
programme.sub-title: Chameleon Lime Whoopiepie and Suzuhana Yuko
programme.desc: Join May J. for music from Chameleon Lime Whoopiepie (getting international attention for their free-spirited style) and vocalist Suzuhana Yuko, who fuses rock with traditional Japanese instruments. On Demand until February 14, 2026

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Konnyaku is an important element of Japanese cuisine. It has long been known as a high-fiber, diet-friendly food, and in recent years it's been shown to offer health benefits such as reducing the risk of dementia and lowering blood sugar levels. Konnyaku is a chewy, jelly-like food made from the extremely bitter corm of the konjac plant. How is it processed? And what other uses does it have? We observe how it's made and look at the many dishes that incorporate this surprising food.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Toyama: The Fruits of a Fall Harvest
programme.desc: A cat patrols the rice fields, but there's always time for a midday nap. At a vineyard, we get a tour from a cat named Pinot Noir! He's popular with visitors but always plays it cool. Corrected on July 17, 2024: Program information on an earlier version of this page was incorrect.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.sub-title: Angra do Heroismo, Terceira Island, Portugal
programme.desc: Located on Terceira Island, about 1000 kilometers off the coast of Portugal, the designated World Heritage site of Angra do Heroismo is a port town which flourished during the Age of Exploration.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: EKIBEN JAPAN
programme.sub-title: A Bento that Brings Comfort at an Old Train Station
programme.desc: The carefully made Kareigawa Bento, featuring local Kagoshima cuisine, is sold at a wooden train station more than 120 years old, which tells the story of people brought together by the ekiben.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Hinoki Bark Thatching: The Age-old Skills for Roofing
programme.desc: World Heritage Kiyomizu-dera's main-hall is thatched with Hinoki cypress bark. Discover how tradesmen uphold this building tradition, sustained by craftsmanship and faith.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #45 Asking someone to repeat and clarify
programme.desc: Today: asking someone to repeat and clarify. Do Cong Uan, from Vietnam, works at a metalworking company. He came to Japan eight years ago with his wife. At his job, he helps to shape metal parts and he also mentors junior coworkers. Though he has no trouble with everyday Japanese, he says he struggles when he encounters unfamiliar words. In a roleplay challenge, he must politely ask a superior to repeat and clarify what they said.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Culinary researcher Yokoyama Takako lives in a mountain region. She cans and ferments local produce to make it through the depths of winter; work supported by nature's bounty and ancestral wisdom.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Japan's Ongoing Challenges
programme.sub-title: The Long Path to Gender Equality
programme.desc: Forty years ago, Akamatsu Ryoko, a visionary woman advocated for the passage of Japan's Equal Employment Opportunity Act. Now, a new generation continues the fight for gender equality.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: This time we break down "kimedashi," a power move where a rikishi locks their opponent's arms and marches them out of the ring. We analyze technique, style, and the risks of the maneuver.

programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN Highlights
programme.desc: We explore Osaka, a prefecture known for its great cuisine. We meet a couple who fish for daggertooth pike conger (hamo), which taste great in summer, a farmer growing juicy eggplants, and much more.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: When Rockie drops and loses one of her pencils, she hardly misses it, but the other pencils feel sad and go on a quest to find their lost sibling. Educational theme: Moderation and temperance.

programme.title: u&i
programme.sub-title: Episode 7: He Might End Up Alone
programme.desc: "i" will be moving away, but there's something worrying her. Her childhood friend "u" tends to suddenly yell and throw things for no reason, and his classmates now avoid him. "i" comes up with a plan.

programme.title: Chatroom Japan
programme.desc: Bui Thi Le Dung is a medical interpreter passionate about supporting Vietnamese residents in Japan. She provides her services for free, fueled by a desire to make medical care accessible to everyone.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Climate Change in Asia ep. 2: Indonesia Struggles With Forest Megafires
programme.desc: With its flammable peatlands, Indonesia's forest fires are among the most serious in Asia. Peatlands release 20 times normal CO2 when burned, causing damage to the atmosphere and natural resources.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Ishikawa Prefecture / Tagawa Kinya (Design engineer) Tagawa investigates the process of design by looking at the work of Yanagi Sori, who shaped products by making models using different materials.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.desc: We meet English-born Roland Gregory, a.k.a. Roly, who runs his own apple orchard in the Nagano countryside, and Gethmina Dinithika from Sri Lanka, who works at a ramen shop in Ueda, also in Nagano Prefecture.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: The Murakami Kaizoku were seafarers and fighters in the Seto Inland Sea. We explore their history and legacy, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time, the Kurushima Straits.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: Uncovering the Mysteries of Winter Lightning
programme.desc: In Japan, extremely powerful lightning known as a superbolt can occur in the Hokuriku region during winter. What is the source of this power, which is comparable to a small nuclear explosion?

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode features words related to neru, meaning "to sleep." Some data show that Japanese people average around only 7 hours of sleep a day, suggesting that many need more slumber. In fact, the Japanese language has a number of unique words related to sleep that describe various aspects of daily life. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through these expressions and the culture behind them.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #6 Does this train go to Ikebukuro?
programme.desc: Find out how to ask if public transportation goes to your destination. Use the name of the place plus "ni ikimasu ka".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: A Safe and Comfortable Society for All
programme.desc: A Sri Lankan student participates in the Mie Prefecture "Youth Police Supporters" volunteer program that works with communities to build a safer society by preventing crimes before they occur.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: "IMPACTS" uses science and data to convey the reality of climate change. A November series-coinciding with the COP30 summit in Brazil-featured five COP-related shows and an Amazon rainforest special.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Suppai - The Secrets of Japan's Sour Treats
programme.desc: In Japan, the word for sourness is suppai. Since ancient times, people in Japan have preserved foods through fermentation. Sour Japanese tastes include vinegar, pickled plums and yuzu, a citrus fruit. Sour Japanese foods are often tied to culture and tradition. In one example, we see how, in Okinawa Prefecture, the juice of the shikwasa, another citrus fruit, is used to wash traditional bashofu cloth.

programme.title: KABUKI KOOL
programme.desc: The historic figure of Minamoto no Yoshitsune has been immortalized in many kabuki plays as a child, a skilled warrior and a tragic hero. Explore with actor Kataoka Ainosuke.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Exquisite Creations Inspired by Nature: Hosono Hitomi / Ceramic Artist
programme.desc: Hosono Hitomi's botanically themed ceramics are highly acclaimed and held in museum collections across the world. She talks about her intricate designs and unmatched technique.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: capsule beds.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Fashioning One-of-a-Kind Costumes: Ito Satomi / Costume Designer
programme.desc: Ito Satomi has designed costumes for many top-tier figure skaters from Japan and overseas. She shares her passion and inspiration for her craft.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.desc: A US rapper, who discovers the legacy of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, is moved to meet hibakusha and join anti-nuclear groups. He sees parallels between their discrimination and that of African Americans.

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: In this episode, the father has become obsessed with a trendy beauty item for mice: the tail roller. Unaware of stealth marketing, his daughter must educate him about the importance of being aware of online promotion. Stealth marketing is now regulated in many countries, including Japan, where the new Consumer Affairs Agency guidelines state that even posts labeled as an advertisement can count as stealth marketing if consumers can't easily recognize the difference.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE: Folding Fans
programme.desc: We visit a store selling folding fans, where a young customer is having trouble making up his mind. The accessories were popular because the shape of the open fan symbolized increasing prosperity.

programme.title: MICE MEDIA
programme.desc: Slander has become a major problem across social media. This time, the father becomes outraged when he learns his favorite influencer has a new love interest. In a rush of anger, he posts insults on social mediaunaware of the dangers of online slander. His daughter tries to stop him, but is she too late? Even if you think you're "in the right," a single post can cause lasting harm. And remember, even anonymous posts are not always completely private and may be subject to disclosure through legal or official actions.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Suppai - The Secrets of Japan's Sour Treats
programme.desc: In Japan, the word for sourness is suppai. Since ancient times, people in Japan have preserved foods through fermentation. Sour Japanese tastes include vinegar, pickled plums and yuzu, a citrus fruit. Sour Japanese foods are often tied to culture and tradition. In one example, we see how, in Okinawa Prefecture, the juice of the shikwasa, another citrus fruit, is used to wash traditional bashofu cloth.
